asset.title: Opinion: Our shared reality – and the knowledge that undergirds it – is being assaulted

nodes.body: It's been known for centuries and quietly acknowledged by a great many people,there simply is no cure for stupidity.
We may be on the fast track to an I diocracy.
Who knew that Idiocracy would be *the* dystopian future to fear?
That attitude led to the events in Ottawa. Smug, condescending urbanites sneering at the working class won’t heal or unify.
The protestors in Ottawa were not representative of the working class.
And: Pierre Trudeau  was first  off the landing craft at Normandy on June 6, 1944.

The events in Ottawa were contrived by people who hijacked a protest for their own purposes. Had it been only the tiny minority of truckers who showed up it would have faded quickly but the manipulators of Canada Unity, the Maverick Party et al gave this legs and loot that would not have normally have had. But hey, you keep working that divisive language, it’s your trademark.
The truckers have 30% support for ending mandates.  This is 10 million Canadians.
Only 10 million?  That sounds like a fringe minority, with unacceptable views .. LOL
And there are at least 28 million who don’t. Democracy. Read up on it. It’s great.

93% of Canadians wanted action taken against the protestors, meaning they did not support them in the least.  The Ottawa occupation made Canadians less open to the protestors ideals.

That leaves only 2 million people who did not want action taken, not exactly support. 

https://angusreid.org/trudeau-convoy-trucker-protest-vaccine-mandates-covid-19/

This link was shared in the John Ibbitson editorial.

Facts are inconvenient, please ignore.
Would have thought that 100% of Canadians want to see an end to mandates. However, most wanted the transition to be lawful, planned and fair.

The problem,  in my opinion,  is that public health agencies are staffed by qualified professionals who understand epidemiology.   They are likely aware that their policies will have both positive and negative effects, but perform modeling to reduce harm to a minimum.
I think it would be fine to ask the agencies about the efficacy of certain policies, but to run into the Capital and demand such policies be implemented without any expertise or data to support your position is foolhardy.

There are also fundamental (sort of) rights that Canada has attempted to encode in the Charter that are supposedly not supposed to be at the whim of majoritarian politics. What is fundamental, and how those fundamental terms are interpreted once they've been encoded (in, say, a Charter) is not a settled question. An inability to understand that majoritarian power and fundamental rights are both aspects of democracy, and that the relationship of the two to each other, is apparently a failure of our education system, and more deeply of the reasoning and imaginative powers of our population.

Read up on it. It's great.

Not a majority, but then the Liberals won with 33.1%  of the votes.

#honkifyoulovetrudeau

I know many working class people, none of them would be caught dead with a confederate flag or a swastika. None of them think vaccines contain microchips, etc. It really isn't, IMHO, a war between snobby elites and workers but between people who will believe nonsense and those who are willing to read and think carefully.

Yet these people who smug elitists wrongly call stupid, redneck and uneducated, effortlessly sent the entire political class and media into complete panic and group nervous breakdown.

The world media is calling the response of all levels of government to the protest possibly the most confused, disorganized, chaotic mess they have ever seen.
The WORLD, you say!

About 25% of the population has an IQ of 90 or less. These same folks don’t read the G&M and its arguable whether they have the ability to understand the risk benefit tradeoffs related to vaccination. It a broader societal problem that needs to be addressed - how should this bottom 25% be respectfully and compassionately engaged in an ever increasing technological and complex society?
A hard working, good person without an abundance of brains will be severely challenged to find satisfying and well compensated role in this economy.
Murmuring comfort to power is standard practice for a reactionary press barricaded inside the gates with their Power Couple mates from The Party.
Inane insinuations is standard practice for those who simply do not know.
"Power Couple mates from The Party" would be a great name for a Netflix series.

All great truths begin as blasphemies.


George Bernard Shaw
Which “great truths” are these, Parsons? I suspect they smack of disinformation.
But very few blasphemies become great truths.

That is very true but establishment condemnation of contrarian assertions as being heretical  or blasphemous is a serious problem and one indulged in here: Painting working class disillusionment  as some form of dangerous infantile ignorance to be therapeutically  'cured'.

There is no working class disillusionment over vaccines and the occupation in Ottawa did not represent that.

Yes, there is working class disillusionment over numerous other issues.
Funny that you’re quoting a capital-S Socialist.
Excellent commentary as always from AC.
No, AC is part of the problem. This is an arrogant column.

Sadly, Andrew, the answer is 'not very.' Indeed this keeps me awake at night. The level of vitriol associated with competing sets of facts threatens to eat us alive. What's most infuriating is that otherwise intelligent people in elected positions and owners of major media companies are prime culprits in propagating fiction dressed as fact for political or material gain. They are knowing accomplices to societal decline.

The only issue I take with your post is the assertion that there are competing sets of facts. Facts are facts. Facts can evolve over time and we can seek to clarify them, but we can’t supplant them with something else and deem the something else to be facts on a par with actual facts. It was a matter of people working from commonly understood facts but having different opinions about what the appropriate response should be, then dialogue would be possible; however, there is no dialogue to be had when one side will not accept the facts and insists that their “something else” be given greater weight than the truth.

if you want to get philosophical about it, there is not absolute truth, which your "facts are facts" implies . . . i think the problem today is the inability to define a shared truth, a common set of values that we can agree is the truth . . .

Here’s a few facts:

1. The root cause of the protest has never about anti-vax. It was about onerous testing mandates.

2. Allegations that the truckers are “white supremist” are ridiculous and inflammatory.

3. Claims that this was an “insurrection” are utter nonsense.
There is no such thing as “competing sets of facts.”

Of course there are - in the minds of those who think they possess them. This is exactly the problem Coyne is talking about. People can't agree on a single set of facts because one side is plainly relying on non-factual or distorted information.
There aren't competing sets of facts.  There are competing interpretations of the meaning of those facts.

Unless you subscribe to Trump presidential aide Kellyanne Conway's concept of "alternate facts".

Of course, you are correct. As the late Sen. Daniel Moynihan observed, "Everyone is entitled to his own opinion, but not his own facts".
Of course there are. You need to start a long journey of education on persuasion, propaganda and power. Start with Scott Adams.

Another question to add to the list at the end of this piece:

Was it wise leadership on the part of the government to refuse to meet with a group of Canadians who, however misinformed and misguided, had made a trip to Ottawa, largely in good faith, to make their concerns heard?

Such a meeting would not have been a negotiation, it would have been reaching out to group of Canadians hurt and confused by the pandemic to bridge the information divide that Andrew Coyne identifies in this piece.

As The Economist wrote: "A wise government would listen to them and respond politely, taking their complaints seriously and patiently explaining why covid restrictions, though onerous, are necessary for the time being."  (https://www.economist.com/leaders/justin-trudeaus-crackdown-on-protests-could-make-things-worse/21807707)
We have got to stop that question. They were “insisting” that the Trudeau government be thrown out. You can’t legitimize such actions or demands by discussing them.

I'm unsure who the "they" is you are referring to? I'm in the US now and have watched many protesters interviews done by left and right leaning news organizations. They all state they want mandates removed and nothing about overthrowing the government. You are always going to get a few that want anarchy, but I doubt this represents the majority.
Then you never read their "MOU" it states clearly there that the government should be forced to resign and that they and some of their supporters would be the new government

You can tell who only watches legacy media in Canada.  The NY Times, Wall Street journal and many from the around the world have reported on the convoy.  They state it was peaceful, disruptive, and no evidence of far-right or coup attempts.
Read the MOU of the organizers.
No they didn't.

Peaceful?  Let's look at some of their behavior:

* (probably) Tried to burn down an apartment building then tape the doors shut so that people couldn't escape
* Attempted Swatting (wrong Ottawa) and bomb threats to 2 hospitals
* Flooding 911 with calls
* Leader says "The only way this thing will be solved is with bullets"... and then they bring their kids along
* Death threats to any tow truck company that attempts to tow their vehicles
* Blockading streets without leaving any room for ambulances/fire trucks to get by

That's not peaceful!

Threatening sexual assault.
Throwing garbage and feces at pedestrians.
Harassing the elderly on their residential streets.
Intimidating journalists.
Why make this up? I don't get it.

Yes, one of the protestors made a bizarre MOU and put it online.

But come on.  Every single protest group has a website, and on it you will reliably find some bizarre claim of overthrowing the government, ending capitalism, blowing up pipelines, or forcibly taking land back from colonists.

Any number of large protests include communist, antifa and anarchist flags.  Sometimes they hang them on statues, include the Terry Fox statue.

But for some reason none of these protest groups have their bank accounts frozen ...

Nelson100 says: "Yes, one of the protestors made a bizarre MOU and put it online"

That would be the one that 320,000 people signed before it was taken down in disgrace?  The website is still bragging about that number.    Minimizing it by calling it "one of the protestors" is part of the problem.
You’re. This has become so crazy that the GG has had to issue a statement reminding Canadians that she can’t change the government on her own.
You cannot meet with thugs.  There are elected representatives who can bring up their concerns.
Trudeau met with BLM. What’s your point?
Firstly, I don't that's true.  Secondly, BLM was not trying to overthrow the government nor blockade a major Canadian city.

I believe it was correct not to meet with this group. I don't see evidence that they made the trip "largely in good faith". They purported to represent "truckers", most of whom were vaccinated and moving freight. Their organization and funding was by those whose opposition to the government long preceded COVID.  There is plenty of work for drivers who wish to remain unvaccinated and stay north of the US/Canada border, so the very basis of their argument was unsupported. Their stated purpose was to replace the democratically elected government, and they absurdly proposed an interim government made up of themselves, the opposition parties and the GG. 
The government has spent months patiently explaining the necessity of COVID protections, to little avail. One can only enter into productive, rational discussion with the rational, and little reason was expressed by the fear-mongering against vaccines nor the wild accusations of "tyranny" against the federal government.
how did that work out .... pure arrogance not to at least have a meeting

Disagree. Their views were well known before they arrived in Ottawa ( or Coutts, or Windsor). Do you really think they were open to dialogue? No amount of ‘explaining’ would have made them pack up and leave. 
Gravel was thrown at Trudeau during a campaign stop - imagine confronting this ‘mob’ what might have happened.

The trucking convoy were also the people our Prime Minister said in 2020 were our ‘ hero’s’ because they crossed the border to bring back food and necessary supplies to the ROC at their own risk.   For that reason it would have been a smart move for the PM to meet for a brief time with the leaders in private with his security detail, let them explain their concerns and in return listen to his reasoning.  It might not have made any difference but I think many Canadians would have been satisfied that there had been some dialogue instead of name-calling.

Thank you for a moderate post.  As a thrice-vaxxed senior woman, I sympathized with the group of Canadians coming to Ottawa to express their frustration with the vaccine mandates that have been imposed, and who deserved a hearing of their concerns.  The dismissal of their concerns by the PM and his government, and the vitriol and name-calling by PM Trudeau to his fellow citizens, who have a different point of view than his, is disheartening  I particularly like the quote from The Economist above.  This is not a wise government.

When the associations that represent truckers in Canada disagreed with the convoy and protests, and were 90% vaccinated, wouldn't it have made more sense to congregate outside the offices of their industry representation, and demand discussions with their leadership about their position on vax mandates? Nope - straight to Ottawa to disrupt innocent Canadians' lives unnecessarily.

If there is a reason mandates and restrictions are about to be eased, it's thanks to those we accepted vaccines, and all other health care recommendations.

There was no way, and there should never be a way, in which these people should be afforded an audience with the PM.

With the advent of artificial intelligence, it’s relatively easy to adjust algorithms to make a group of people believe what they want to hear. If your group hates the government, or better, Justin Trudeau, the algorithms will find you and feed you all the necessary information. The same goes for those who oppose vaccines and so on. 
When I was growing up in the 50’s and 60’s many citizens thought and believed the purpose of government was to protect ourselves from ourselves. In 2022, apparently, the sitting government hasn’t fulfilled its mandate. Thanks to bots, overseas bad actors, our most impressionable, vulnerable citizens need education more than ever. These protests/ occupations were born out of ignorance and manufactured hatred. Nothing has changed.

Sorry but that is a weird comment.  I don't support the blockades, but with all my sentient intelligence I do not support JT or his government - and no bot made me feel that way, but instead my own thinking about the failures of him as a leader and of this government.  Nothing to do with overseas bad actors and bots influencing my thinking.

There is no question, with the variety of media available, most people only read media that reinforces their initial viewpoint.  Confirmation bias.

However it’s only fair to acknowledge that those that believe that the truckers protest is part of some mysterious “alt-right” conspiracy are living in a fantasy world as distantly removed from reality as people who believe that vaccines are bad.

Coyne continues to misunderstand this event. Yes, there were many uninformed people in the protest. But the majority are resisting government over-reach and the suppression of civil rights for a virus that has a 99.9% survival rate. Vaccine mandates are an over-reach. I'm vaccinated, well-informed and I oppose mandates.

Sure but why block streets and harass locals for 3 weeks?

How does that help the cause?

Everyone wants mandates gone but we arent camping out in someone's front lawn
People in the thousands have been protesting for two months across Canada.  It was ignored by legacy media.  This got people noticing and helped eliminate mandates in many provinces.
Tens of millions have not protested, and support vaccine mandates.

The truckers likely expected the police to kick them out after a few days.  Who wouldn't?

They would have made their point, and left.

But the woke dysfunctional Ottawa municipal government and police force let them stay for weeks.  So they said, "why not?"  They were having what appeared to be a fun party.

At a certain point the political class snapped, had a complete nervous breakdown, and overreacted about a thousand times. 

In a complete frenzied panic they suddenly went for the nuclear option and turned Canada into a police state ... to compensate for their utter incompetence.

And down into a mind sewer goes the Nelson again....  

Somehow the authorities were both "woke" and "nuclear". That's quite the feat.

So it's not the truckers fault because the police didn't kick them out  after a few days ?

Most people stop using excuses like that sometime around nursery school.

Very well put. I am in total agreement.  When the Covid was more deadly and there was a science led view that unvaccinated could spread it at a higher rate, Vaccine mandates might have made some sense as a time limited option.  But now - they don’t.  Unfortunately, our leaders are more interested in creating polarization for political gain.  We need to join the rest of the world and lift mandates.
As you say vaccinated, well informed not so much.
Well written comment. So are you going to park yourself outside Coyne’s house and blare your horn all day long?

I always distrust the use of the figure 99.1%. It is regularly used to either minimize a situation or give an argument more credibility than it actually has. Actual numbers are there to see: Canada, relative to many other countries, including the US, saved thousands of its citizens’ lives and avoided (barely) the collapse of its heathcare system by imposing restrictions and encouraging vaccinations. Supply chain shortages globally are being caused in large part by factories and distribution points being shut down or severely hampered by labour absences due to COVID. Mandates became necessary because truckers are essential to every stage of that chain. The vast majority of truckers understood that and voluntarily got vaccinated.

Thousands of Canadians have died this year -- since Jan. 1, 2022 -- of Covid-19.

If all you think about is "survival rate" you are missing so much of the picture.

I'm vaccinated, well-informed and I oppose mandates.

As am I and basically everyone I know.  I was in favour of very strong restrictions on the unvaccinated until it became patently obvious that vaccines don’t stop the spread. That was in the late fall at the earliest arrival of omicron in Africa.  Public health refuses to listen or acknowledge the concept of natural infection as a form of immunity.

One of the main issues is that a large portion of population does not feel represented by the government or media, forcing them to alternative and sometimes extreme avenues.

I can admit that even having read multiple MSM sources, independent journalists and social feeds I still do not know the truth about the protest and protesters.

When we are so concerned with promoting our own values and shaping the truth to that, as a byproduct distrust increases.

What's not to know?  It was all on live tv for days on end 

We all saw first hand their actions and hears their words and interviews 

Nothing ambiguous about it unless you didn't bother to watch and read what's before your eyes

You mean the cherry picked interviews and images with talking heads weaving the message?

Think about how much space a single flag took up.

No, that did not provide an accurate picture.

If you watched, listened, and read a variety of traditional news sources over the course of the occupation, you would have heard from lots of the participants. I estimate that I heard at least 50 different peoples' comments on why they were involved or supporting the protest.  

Every news report is going to be "cherry picked" as they can't interview everybody for a news report.  Even the people inside the protest livestreaming are "cherry picking" as they decide what to show and not show.
So, Nellis  what are you waiting to read or view? What story points would constitute the real motive of the protesters, to you?

I watched hours and hours of footage, read and watched dozens of interviews, not to mention seeing all the abuse thrown at reporters, etc.

It's all right there to see - no media lense required - you can see for yourself how these people act and think.  It's not a secret.  They'll gladly tell you and many do.  Even in these forums people aren't shy to tell you their views.  So we can all see with our very eyes, no media required, what's really going on and who these people are. 

It's right there in the open, on live tv
Apparently, there's still a large part of the population that thinks border controls are going to have any effect on the transmission of Omicron amongst the general population.

Thata irrelevant though 

You dont get to do whatever you want.  Life isnt fair.  Work to change it through proper means and otherwise do what everyone does - what you have to.

Thata irrelevant though

Sorry, I thought the topic was about groups of ignorant people zealously supporting the malformed opinions of their leaders.

It's about people purposely spreading misinformation in an attempt to get what they want

That's the root issue

And then blocking streets, harassing businesses, etc. for weeks on end as some sort of "revenge" plot.

It's about people purposely spreading misinformation in an attempt to get what they want

So, you're coming around then.

Right, 

People don’t believe in vaccines wrong

People who institute scientifically void border controls, well thats all we have.

If the media and the government in the UK (and many other nations) believe its time to drop the mandates, yet the Canadian government and (obedient) media believe otherwise, then at least one segment of mainstream media must be spreading disinformation, no?

Here is the main question that the Vaccine hesitant had, and, for anyone to associate this with "bad information"  your the problem. What are the long term effects to the Immune system taking this new drug?
That's it, that was the whole enchilada.  Is it 100% safe and effective, absolutely not, if you say it is you've not researched or read near enough.  It absolutely looks like it did what it was meant to do, but, with this clinical trial being in its first 12 months there is no way to be sure.  We told the unvaxxed to stay home and we limited what they did, and, they for the most part did what they were told.  Now, as the numbers have gone down and we all wait for the next Strain the facts point to being vaccinated don't really affect society anymore, and, as more and more countries realize this our Federal govt not only refused to even talk but they doubled down with hate speech and some of the most disgusting language aimed at the very Citizens they are to serve.  So here we are.  I really like Andrew Coyne, I think he's the best writer in this country, I just disagree with him on this.
You mean to the people with F Trudeau signs?
It’s not a drug- there you go

There is no more of a risk with these vaccines than with your yearly flu vaccine. It simply contains something that imitates the virus so that your system recognizes it as such and produces antibodies to fight it.That’s all. Period. As for the convoy, what reason would a government have to meet with its representatives when those representatives are demanding that they either give in to their minority demands or resign and for the GG to somehow intervene? Do you honestly think the majority of Canadians would have stood for that, especially after doing their part by following strict guidelines and getting vaccinated? The harshest language I heard was Trudeau calling them misinformed, which they were. I realize most of the protesters probably disagreed with the White Supremacists and neo-Nazis who joined their ranks, but they should have spent as much energy denouncing the presence of such people as they did expressing their discontent over mandates. Finally, the relaxation of restrictions in other countries was concurrent with the event and not part of the reason for it.

Legitimate question and legitimate concern Bill. 

I won't pretend for a moment to effectively answer your question as there is a lot of information from legitimate scientific based sources that you can read.  

Reality is the long term side effects aren't known but based on facts of the vaccines given in the past haven't had any long term effects.

What is becoming well known is the long term and short term effects of Covid for many of the people that have caught it.  

Many of us have chosen to err on the side of caution and get vaccinated d/t the fact that getting covid would have a far worse outcome on our health and the people around us.
Your questions would best be answered by taking a grade 9 biology class.

So you "really like Andrew Coyne, [you] think he's the best writer in this country", after claiming he got everything in this article wrong.

Why would I believe anything you say ?
Beautifully written Mr. Coyne. It’s frightening and worrisome that so many of our neighbours have become infected by this “ disease of disinformation.”
The sad part is that "our neighbours" probably feel the same about us.

Considering that the CBC claimed that the trucker's strike was orchestrated by Russia, perhaps it's time to acknowledge that the media can sometimes have a bad case of the "disease of disinformation."

And when people lose faith in the mainstream media, they turn to social media and  other sources.

I don't disagree with the premise of the column, but suggest that Coyne needs to include the Canadian media as a more than occasional contributor to disinformation.

Thanks for your comments.  I agree.  Main stream media is not the "pure truth" that some on this site have said, particularly as it has been subsidized with $600,000,000. of taxpayers money from the current government, whom they are supposed to be fiercely questioning.  Our "free press" is nothing of the sort; it is a complementary media to government proclamations, which is detrimental to a democratic nation

I will try again - I don't think there was good faith shown by this bunch of folk.  Vaccinated truck drivers trying to get across in Alberta reported harassment of a particularly odious kind - their choice was not respected by this bunch.  Obscene signs loudly displayed on the sides of the rigs in Ottawa and displaying our flag upside down?  If anything, all levels of government should have nipped this in the bud immediately instead of waiting 3 weeks.  You don't talk with bullies.
The truck protest is still in Edmonton.

If what this columnist says is true, then it is largely the result of a massive failure by the education system and the mainstream media, both of which are instrumental in shaping what we believe and how we think. And yet both constantly tell us what a great job they are doing and dismiss criticism as unfounded or not progressive enough.

I'm trying to recall articles by Mr. Coyne specifically or the G&M and other media in general  "constantly tell[ing] us what a great job they are doing and dismiss criticism as unfounded or not progressive enough" and failing.
What is missing here is a mea culpa. Journalism has failed in the social media age. Why has this happened and what can be done about it are missing questions.

As someone who isn't on social media, tell me how journalism has failed?  If you look at a lot of the posts people make on Twitter, they are usually referencing articles from the mainstream media.

The only failure journalism has in this era is the business model to support good journalism.

Bang on as usual

Some are so desperate to believe what they want they'll listen to anyone who tells it to them

That said I truly believe that deep down most of these people know they're wrong.  They just can never admit it or their world view crashes down

But deep down they know they're wrong

Another well-written opinion. I do wonder if in all cases the people behind the disinformation are spreading it knowing what they are doing. Certainly in many cases, but it is more alarming to think that even the instigators are convinced of their own lies. On another note, is the Globe aware that the ad on this page is blocking part of the text. This same ad appears in other articles with same result. Very annoying.

This article goes off on a few directions. But let's say we stick to covid and the perceived 'right think' vs 'wrong think', as Coyne has stated above. 

In Canada, the 'right think' has stood by lockdown measures. Yet we have just seen one of the most extensive studies on lockdowns by John Hopkins that showed minimal benefit. Without measuring societal harms. 

That 'right think' stood by vaccinating everyone multiple times. 'Wrong think' in Canada is questioning passports, mandates, and children receiving three vaccines. Yet, we have seen elected officials and CMOH across the country admit to the limitations of passports. Other western allies are not vaccinating children as young as 5. 

Are those 'wrong think' views than considered disinformation?

The working paper (Johns Hopkins did not present it as a study) you cite was done by economists.  Smart people, no doubt, but not expert in their field.  It is true that Johns Hopkins published it, but with the proviso that it had not been peer-reviewed, which is the de facto standard for validating a study.

There are ample data showing that restrictions (we never had lockdowns and it is facile to believe we did) helped reduce transmission, particularly before vaccines were administered.  They did not (and could not) eliminate disease, but they did keep infections to a more manageable level, reducing strain on health care and perhaps saving lives.

And yet a single working paper by people not expert in their fields and yet to be validated by those who are is constantly waved as proof that those data and legions of people who are expert in the field were wrong.

Could it be that you suffer from the malaise Coyne articulates so well in his essay?

I read Johns Hopkins quite often. Practically every study first published is not peer reviewed. 

I believe there is validity when they publish an article to get vaccinated. 

I believer there is validity when they say the border mandates and some lockdown measures don't work

It is entirely Trumpian to pick and choose which science and alternative facts you want to believe depending on your political narrative.

“depending on your political narrative.”

Political narrative is not the only criteria by which you can judge a study which hasn’t yet been peer reviewed.

Exactly what I said, unfortunately that is not what happens. It is rare for a paper to be published that has already been peer reviewed. However they are latched on to like gospel depending on your political bent.

"It is rare for a paper to be published that has already been peer reviewed."

No, it isn't.

Self-published on someone's personal page on a university web site doesn't count.

And, relying on one cherry-picked meta-analysis (which included only one epidemiological study in its selection) to support your views is indeed Trumpian.

You're allowed to question lockdowns that normal

But don't block streets and harass locals for 3 weeks straight, and don't purposely spread misinformation to try and win the argument

Alot of posters are missing the point.  Doubts and dissent is fine - what you DO with those is what matters

I think part of the problem here, is to treat those who are joining this populist bonfire of the vanities, as under the influence of bad ideas and bad people.  The reason they are splitting from traditional right-of-centre and left-of-centre parties, is that they are tired of being talked down to and told how to act and what to think.   Using social media, they have discovered that lots of other people share both their positive ideals and their darker fears and hatreds. That reassures them and they have decided that since their new community approves of what they say, it is okay to be themselves.  And that is a person -- as we all are including myself-- of imperfect character.  In their case they have decided it is now okay to act on the fear and hate they have long felt towards others: Be those others gays, Jews, women, people who follow public health guidelines, or those who like to put little bows in the hair of their Yorkshire Terriers, whatever, it doesn't really matter.  This is what it looks like when people decide it is okay to slip the ties of civilized behavior.  The rules that should lead each of us to exercise self-control over the worst part of our characters.
An interesting take.

I was with you right up until that dig about bows in the hair of Yorkshire Terriers.

Still, I'll overlook that: good analysis.

The woke mobs currently running rampant in modern society have the most significant similarities with the "bonfire of the vanities."

That is if you are referring to February 1497, when fanatic supporters of the friar Girolamo Savonarola collected and burned thousands of objects such as cosmetics, art, and books in the public square of Florence, Italy (not the Tom Wolfe book)
In other words, what Trump said out loud. But I get your point.

I believe that there are many reasons why people choose not to follow the science and norms of society, and I do agree that there is a knowledge gap.

One of those reasons is the feeling of a lack of control that some people feel over their lives. By choosing not to follow the societal norms they are “taking control of their lives”. It reminds me of anorexia.

Yes, intellectual anorexia!

What a great metaphor, maybe it will gain currency.

excellent analogy.
I will starve my body to save my soul from a world I fear.
I will starve my mind . . .
My mother used to call this "cutting off your nose to spite your face."
Sounds very Catholic.

Reminds me of rebellious teenagers -- the ones whose sense of not having to do anything they don't like leads to all kinds of dead ends in life. Starting at home ("you're not the boss of me") and school -- the socialization problem Coyne flags is all through this tale of a sorry Children's Crusade. More grownups needed.

In a knowledge based complex society and economy, those who have the capability will get ahead.  Those that do not will be frustrated as the tasks that they used to do get outsourced or automated and they find their lot in life getting worse.   They will then latch on too any reason that will say why they are getting the shaft.  That number is growing and will continue to grow.  Get ready as this divide increases and these people are used as wedges for power from the right.
So: Those who know how to repair your complex computerized automobile will be at a great advantage over those who do not have even operating a tire gauge or car jack in their 'knowledge base'?
False dichotomy.

1. Brian Peckford was not a signatory of the Charter.  The Constitution Act, 1982 (which contains it) was signed by 4 people: Queen Elizabeth, PM Pierre Trudeau, AG Jean Chretien, and Registrar General André Ouellet.

Read Section 1 of the Charter. You'll find our rights are not absolute, that governments may place 'reasonable limits on them. So to simply claim, as you do, that various 'mandates' violate our rights is meaningless  -  the question is whether any 'violations' (or, more to the point, limits) are reasonable.

Who decides if limits are reasonable? The courts, not Team Peterbilt. In fact, the Charter very specifically says, in Section 24:  

(1) Anyone whose rights or freedoms, as guaranteed by this Charter, have been infringed or denied may apply to a court of competent jurisdiction to obtain such remedy as the court considers appropriate and just in the circumstances.


You might then read the rest of the Charter. You'll find (I've dealt with this 'talking point' before) that it does not include a right to 'seek a livelihood'. It does include a right 'to pursue the gaining of a livelihood in any province'. But that's section 6 of the Charter, titled 'mobility rights'. It's the 'in any province' part that's the important bit.

Each side in the vax debate claims the other suffers from a failure to apply their reason to a problem. Yet it’s not an exercise in reason that is called for. Few of us are able to assess by “thinking for ourselves” the efficacy or safety of vaccines or the cost-benefit vs COVID. What is required is epistemic trust. The vaccinated, at some level, put their trust in socially-created knowledge - they trust some of their compatriots, and people in other lands, who have acquired knowledge by study and give their blessing to vaccination. The anti-vax people say these people are too trusting and should “think for themselves” “do their own research”. 

There must be a restoration of social and epistemic trust before there can be any effort to get people to “think for themselves”.

There's no such thing as unbiased reporting. Every reporter who's ever reported on anything, however momentous or trivial, has had biases. Bias is part of the default setting of every mind, integral to our  perception, reasoning, understanding, and memory. It shapes our connections and allegiances. It's inescapable, and reporters and journalists are just as prone to bias as the rest of us.

However, well-trained, experienced reporters are aware--or at least try to be aware--of their biases and inclinations, and they acknowledge them and attempt to compensate for them when necessary. Some are better at this than others. In a well-run news outlet, experienced, capable and wise editorial oversight consistently encourages that awareness and helps cultivate that compensation.
